tweet.text: working
continuing to search ...
is in DC visiting Laura Bush with the Cooper-Hewitt.
is preparing for risdjogs.ning.com
is writing about Scott Stowell on our.risd.edu
is pondering the difference between orange juice and fizzy water.
is understanding the word 'research' in multiple contexts as being the same in principle.
is at Harvard learning how to be a president.
is contemplating the brilliance of a book title he sees "UNKN()WN QUANTITY"
is captivated by the phrase "Less presentation, more discussion."
is wondering what bees think about as they go about business.
is happy to be sentient.
is wondering when books will be simply uploaded to our minds, how will we erase them?
is deeply struck by the correlation between Community and Communication. Connect and Context.
is realizing that "better" is not a subjective target.
is certain that complementary colors get along well.
is trying to multitask microtasks but is preparing macrotasks concurrently to increase the value of his time.
is happy to have attended the recent MIT Scratch event with RISD folks.
is noting the "dialog box of life" with options: OK, Cancel, and Be Happy.
is curious about the implications of the sixth and seventh dimensions to art and design.
is fond of channeling JFK, "Ask not what RISD can do for you, ask what you can do for RISD."
is happy when his plane lands, and is unsure of how he would feel if it didn't.
is seeking to secure the future of art and design by empowering its past forms.
is standing two feet from Thom Browne and wondering if he can wear Thom-style pants.
is recalling the moment in his life 8 years ago when he learned the distinction between tactics and strategy.
is reflecting on what Richard Saul Wurman told him today, "Skills shouldn't be taught in schools."
is moved by Gong Szeto's assertion of strategy=idealize vs tactics=realize ... "thoughtful execution" comes to mind as a compromise.
is following the simple Web-like wisdom of "it is better to give than receive."
is confident that there's nothing more stupid than overlooking one's own stupidity.
is regretting he ate amusement park pizza.
is thinking about Randy Pausch today and is being grateful for Randy's memory and to be alive.
is reflecting on Siddartha's acknowledgement of "self" as being a critical turning point.
is struck by the distance that can be achieved between perception and reality. Oddly they can be different, but equally important.
is uploading sixteen ~60Mb files to an online printing service so he doesn't have to buy a lg-format printer.
is wondering if Batman is Buddhist.
is grateful that email traffic slows down after 6pm.
is thinking that disabling all the visual acrobatics on the iPhone 3G would be a great way to save power.
is pondering the future of academia today with more intensity than usual.
is realizing that someone that "manages up" well is not a good manager if they can't do it down and sideways too.
is struck by the important balance between being educated for the long term (life) and for the immediate future (making a living).
is enamored by the true intent of freedom of speech.
is teaching himself how to make iPhone applications.
is curious about how design that satisfies 70% of the need utterly fails to serve the other 30%.
is recalling scene from Batman: "Why do we fall down? To pick ourselves up."
is struck by the level of sincere dedication in the people that he meets every day.
is trying to understand how "cautious optimism" can convert to "unbridled optimism."
is amused by a novel term used for the mood on RISD campus as characterized by "cynical optimism."
is at P&G hq in Cincinatti engaging some of the world's greatest marketers. I feel like buying something.
is easily impressed by the bright lights at night in Times Square.
is powered by hope.
is at a party in NY for the Esquire 75. He met LeBron James, ate mini hamburgers, and is ready to return to RISD.
is all done with his RISD inauguration as the 16th President. Phew.
is happy to make his inauguration speech available online http://our.risd.edu/start-here ...
is through his first Trustee Meeting at RISD. He renewed his determination to imagine what may be.
is a believer in the power of mutual respect.
is learning how to see farther into the future.
is curious about rumors and how they form.
is seeing a gazillion alums and parents here for RISD By Design weekend rbd.risd.edu
is grateful to his father for his lifelong example of personal integrity.
is experiencing loss of right-brain strength. Drew images this morning to revive functionality.
is now able to see the mountain.
is interested in making open communication scalable and respectful somehow. Thinking ...
is making art.
is thinking about Jessie Shefrin's point about when things are turned upside down you get the chance to truly see something for what it is.
is thinking about Jessie Shefrin's point about "artists that make art for the art world" vs "artists that make art for the world."
is spying a T-shirt in NYC that says "NO to Hate!" It seems contradictory to hate hate.
Karten (ID '78)!
is proud of the two RISD alums that took home two separate National Design Awards last night in NYC. Congratulations to Scott Stowell (G ...
is chatting with filmmaker Deborah Scranton about how artists traditionally *conjure* something from nothing. Conjure is the right word.
is likening good education to the art of instilling curiosity in people.
is answering a reporter's question of "What is an artist" with "Someone who does the wrong thing at the right time."
is marveling at the proliferation of LEDs in Halloween garb this year.
is thankful for the outpouring of b-day wishes and realizes he should someday set his FB b-day to the correct date.
is thinking about RISD Provost Jessie Shefrin's point on how we can use the phrase "the big picture" as a metaphor for art and life.
is talking with Providence Mayor David Cicilline about creativity and economic development.
is having fun with RISD alum Ann Harakawa at the ADC gala in NY.
is returning to RISD after being inducted into the Art Director's Club Hall of Fame. NDA winner and RISD alum Scott Stowell made him laugh.
is thinking about the nature of art (school).
is also testing out the new Google G1 phone. Impressive first step.
is startled by how hard iMovie is to operate now.
is en route to giving his Art Director's Club Hall of Fame talk in 30 minutes and realizes he forgot his computer. Slideless! Challenges ...
is thinking about what Maira Kalman said this evening, "Abraham Lincoln never had to go to school and be bored."
is considering the difference between being grounded in theory versus being grounded in the world. Is there one?
is at an off-campus event where 70% of the people here have beards. Awkward.
is saddened by his disbelief when he hears a bird chirping sound that it could come from a real bird instead of a mobile's ringtone.
is inspired by student Aaron Perry-Zucker's generation's belief in the power of open emgagement. Everyone matters.
is reading Lessig's "REMIX" book and is thankfully RENEWED.
is at an American Girl Doll Store -- witnessing the power of fantasy.
is thinking that the younger visionary is good at finding new keys, and the older visionary is good at knowing which doors to open.
is proud of the new viewbook site: http://www.risd.edu/undergraduate -- a sign of things to come.
is acknowledging the difference and relationship between listening and leading.
is smarter for learning from student Kristine Lee that a "good assignment" is one that has a clear purpose.
is thankful on Thanksgiving Day to have the chance to lead RISD.
is thinking how design is about the "well made," and art is about the "well thought." At the intersection lies RISD's authentic voice.
is a believer in "academic freedom" -- especially in an era when the academy's monopoly of knowledge is set free.
is open to thinking openly.
is happy to have learned from Provost Shefrin the important distinction between being transparent ... and being clear.
is thinking how a good student is someone who accepts the possibility of being wrong for the opportunity to learn if s/he may be right.
is thinking how the goal in life is to know that you have lived.
is wondering how many flavors of knowledge there are in the world. Sweet, bitter, tasteless, angry, lemon-lime.
is reflecting on the importance of being awake -- intellectually, spiritually, emotionally, physically.
is thinking about youth as a way of life.
is thinking how in a world where everyone is an author, author(ity) means less.
is wondering whether people still use fax machines.
is remembering how to program in Java.
is considering the subtle difference between contributing versus interfering.
is thinking how positive acts often go unrewarded; negative acts always remain unforgotten. The choice is yours.
is resisting the seduction of conformity.
is wondering whether the Web will ultimately look like one big, gigantic graphic novel.
is thinking how all thoughts we have, no matter how global and grand, start ultra-locally -- deep inside our heads.
is wondering if Rome wasn't built in a day, then what *can* be built in a day?
is thinking how our best work is done when resources (time, materials, etc) are limited because there is no other choice.
is noting how a mirror to one's soul reveals the unseen work that remains -- vanity has an unexpected up side.
is relecting on how a good teacher can make even the most boring of topic matter to be somehow exciting.
is thinking how education is about unlocking the freeing power of confidence in oneself.
is open to modern REMIX culture, and notes how every artistic act -- analog or digital -- samples and reorders reality anew.
is noting that great art bridges the artist's private integrity and her public contexts with a timely degree of concern or lack thereof.
is noting how on iTunes, music videos have become a natural stand-in for the elaborate CD packaging we once knew.
is recalling a favorite inspirational phrase, "I'd rather be green and growing, instead of ripe and ready to rot."
is thinking how the quest for perfection can empower (give an impossible goal) or paralyze (give up on the impossible).
is noting how timesaving aids ironically become timewasting aids when you are desperate to recall where you last left them.
is considering the difference between restoration and transformation. The latter is a to; the former is a to-from.
is tickled by barber's response to my Q, "Do you believe in leadership by example?" "Sure. But not if it's a bad example."
is thinking how artist Kelly Dobson's work on "machine therapy" is going to make our world a more hummin' place.
is noting how an aimless walk through the snow can amply satisfy one's goals.
is thinking how a caste system imprisons *everyone* from achieving change -- status quo is defined by status itself.
is wondering if a new year smells different than a used one.
is thinking that if we learn by knowing, then what makes us know how to learn? Practice.
is squinting to see the vanishing fences that once protected intellectual property from making a meaningful difference.
is wondering whether "meaningful" impact is to be measured by depth or breadth. It depends.
is noting how "free thinking" implies unlimited "undo"s for what may be thought or said. To Undo = To Forgive.
is going offline, to go online in the real world.
is wondering how creativity would be impacted if we all stopped using $$-ive software and went open source instead.
is respectful of how teaching even the lightest of seminars requires arduous and advanced preparation.
is resolved in 2009 to recruit the many creatives who dream to lift the spirits and hopes of our challenged world.
is thinking about Jessie Shefrin's point that "problem solving" with a changing problem needs a changing solution.
is noting how fresh ideas often come from professionals that allow ego to give way to the naivete of their youth.
recalls his former producer Enami-san who would say with resolve amidst any chaos, "If I am here, all will be okay."
is thinking how doing something can be the next step after figuring out how to do something. It's up to you.
is noting how although his eyes are naturally weakening with age, with every year of life he can actually see *better*.
recalls being told long ago that "a picture is worth a thousand words ... and yet it takes words to say that."
teaches chess to a child, "A king barely moves and has no power." Her reply, "The king is *most* powerful. If he dies, it's over."
reflects on how talking inspires doing; doing inspires talking. Talking about what you are doing is the real thing.
is enamored by the simplicity of how toddlers can make intellectual arguments: "Because yes." Or, "Because no."
feels the gravity of the challenges we face together globally and locally; lightness not only illuminates, but lifts us up.
is thinking how you can always find the truth around you when you stop looking for it and just listen to what is.
notes the choice between doing some thing vs doing any thing. But doing the right thing is known only after it is done.
is thinking how a sense of community is formed by active, impromptu conversations that speak the truth.
is noting how creativity is not always communicative, but all communication Is creative.
Art allows us to consider the world with the open mind of a child, as an antidote to the isolating effect of an adult life.
is thinking how trust in others is founded upon the doubts we have that get erased with evidence of action.
is wondering when the snowfall completely stops, what else will completely start.
is behind on a few things and is looking to decrease the quantity by multiplying with a number < 1 ad infinitum.
is thinking how "I can" easily turns into "I can-not"; however starting with "I cannot" misses the one chance to "I can."
is locked out of updating http://our.risd.edu but because of "yes we can" he found a way to say to all, and from today forward, yes we can.
is seeing, and thinking. In that exact order.
is reflecting on W+K's John Jay saying, "The most powerful thing in the world you can be is to just be *you*." No one else can.
is reflecting on W+K's John Jay saying, "There are times when symbolism is substance."
is noting how creative teams retain members' individualism to keep group-think at bay. We and I in careful balance.
is testing the premise of "fast" food at McD. 56.9 sec in/out for a single cheeseburger order. He wonders if it is the norm.
is thinking how actions intended to clarify often result in more confusion. However, inaction tends to reveal nothing.
is finding how as a "reality artist" he expresses himself with the actual experiences he finds around him ... as his medium.
is reflecting on a comment by Provost Jessie Shefrin that, "Feeling ... is thinking with your body. That's why it is so real."
is recharged when he speaks with RISD undergrads at dinner in the cafeteria. Teaching happens anywhere.
is humbled by the nature of knowledge and the nurture of action.
is thinking how industry's activities are punctuated with ! and . -- academia's by " " and ? and ,
is considering how "collective intelligence" can degrade to simply "group-think" when the group forgets to think.
@teamretro keep up the good work.
is en route to Davos World Economic Forum to speak on the topic of "creative leadership."
is thinking how the self-centeredness inherent to the referent "I" shifts dramatically when attached to "am sorry."
is noting how easy it is to lose one's creative spirit to the demands of leadership if you forget to be a creative leader. I won't.
is reflecting on Robert Scoble's point at dinner wrt "entertainment vs art" as "popularity vs morality."
is amused by Accel Partner's Joe Schoendorf comment from his old days at HP that, "Marketing people are engineers with personality."
is thinking how courage is a noble form of stupidity that aids getting impossible things done.
is thinking how Facebook is like Second Life but without the "reality" in "virtual reality."
is resolved at Davos that the world's sense of helplessness shall be countered by the Invigorating forces of art and design.
is intrigued by Mozilla's Mitchell Baker comment -- as crowdsourcing gets more popular, "the crowd" is bound to fatigue.
is inversely correlating the speed of the world in the last ten years with how much it has slowed in the last ten months.
@fancyjeffrey Nice. http://tinyurl.com/dxrsma FYI Mitchell's point was made at the Davos panel we were on.
is closer to how the cat thought and felt when the dog stopped noticing him -- able to see through, instead of around.
is reminiscing to when a RISD alumni told him declaratively and emphatically that, "Decoration is purely functional."
is noting how seeing the world through students' eyes is the best way to always remain fresh and sane, http://tinyurl.com/brnxsb
is quoting artist Yann Arthus-Bertrand, "We don't want to believe what we know."
@mihae I can see it both ways.
is fairly certain that when you work your hardest, the only downside is that you get tired. The upsides, however, can be limitless.
is thinking how when your arms are crossed, ideas are deflected from entering your heart. So, open your arms.
is noting artist Olafur Eliasson's elegant point, "Between thinking and doing ... is experience."
is enjoying designer Jacek Utko simple statement, "To be good is not enough." http://tinyurl.com/bcx2rw
is marinating on what actress Glenn Close told him, "Art has the power to rearrange you."
is noting world stat that 1 in 2 people are of Asia, and 30% population in India are under 15 = the total US population.
overheard, "Artists should be thought as more than content providers -- as catalysts that can transform communities."
is struck by Chris Anderson's comment, "Pessimists simply worry; optimists get things done."
notes comment by Alex Tabarrok, "New ideas drive new growth. One apple feeds one man; one idea feeds the world."
is reflecting on last nite's design thinktank dinner at the Eames House. Concluded that new era will bring advances in creative leadership.
is noting the tendency to ignore the ideas right in front of you because they don't play hard-to-get.
is optimistic to empower his creativity, pessimistic to carefully test assumptions, and realistic to see straight and clear.
is thinking how VISION = Prediction (see the future) + Intuition (*feel* the future) + Realization (make the future).
is thinking how entitlement and enlightenment are two very different things.
weighs the distinction between a printed book and an electronic download. The gap closes for reasons of time, not matter.
notes how all crystal balls to see into our future have become like souvenir snow globes shaken, not stirred.
when a student says they love a subject of study, they are saying that they love the teacher even more. Learning is personal.
@elinesca Good point. And the memory of a teacher can be forever as well. To @amandarust -- the answer is that we all have each other now.
is in wonderment from 1st grader's declaration that, "Today is Microsoft Word Day!" Wishing you all a good one.
recalls his father's life mantra of the Japanese aesthetic of "mada dame" (maw-dah dah-may) -- "It's not good enough yet."
is noting how changes happening on the edges always find their way in -- why outside the box is the entrance to the box.
is wondering if domino pieces are more often used to be lined up in long rows instead of played as a proper game.
is reflecting on the difference between doing something just to do it, vs doing something that leads to bigger other somethings.
spoke with former banker that espoused simple finance logic: 1) save more, 2) borrow less, 3) don't invest in anything you don't understand.
was asked by a student debating a choice in major as what she is good at doing versus what she wants to do,
is reflecting on what Prof Charlie Cannon says about the importance of having space to *rehearse* an idea.
believes that artists turn what is only imaginable to some, into that which could otherwise be unrealized.
is listening, steady, and focused.
is still listening, steady, and focused. He will be like that for a *very* long time.
is considering @veek's comment on "role models" and is wishing he had met John Gardner http://tinyurl.com/cx9kfa
am analyzing data on Many Eyes by @wattenberg and @viegasf http://tinyurl.com/cv3wvl to see shifts in high school grad patterns by 2018.
knows that everyone can make an image. But making the image say something extraordinary is not for everyone.
is admiring RISD grad student leader Jessica Roundy's charge to "think critically, and react creatively."
notes how the word "hope" can be used as a noun (goal) or as a verb (imperative). Together they form a state of being.
is chairing the National Design Awards jury. The inventiveness in the USA tells me "Yes we can" design us a future.
notes how the beauty of the snow segues to the sloppy mud. The ground eventually dries, and we can firmly stand once again.
notes how the beauty of the snow segues to the sloppy mud. The ground eventually dries, and we can firmly stand again.
@tinabeans thanks for your "expanding" thought.
notes how when we know where we've been, and know where we are ... we then know where to go next.
is looking forward to the upcoming RISD student-run event, "What We Do" -- http://tinyurl.com/cdab2q
is open to a RISD campus run (technically a "jog") tomorrow night: http://is.gd/nu62
@misterjonah thanks. Hope to see you there. JM
is thinking how a team will win when everyone learns how to depend upon (and trust) one another. Earth, USA, RISD, family - all the same.
is challenged by living in a time when anything is creatively possible but eveything is fiscally improbable.
@damianewens thanks for that insight.
is thinking how subjectivity and passion are traditional hallmarks of the arts, but these times require objectivity and compassion instead.
notes how depth in one's character may be evident at first glance, but only through tireless reinforcement can the disbeliever be turned.
A great image, whether representational or abstract, constantly generates brand new meanings regardless of how well you might know it.
is comfortable with his ponderings realized as a team sport. A team can do great things together when to play as a team becomes the goal.
@efescenmeyer I feel that apathy is an extreme form of objectivity. To "feel"apathy is an oxymoron for certain.
I was sorry to hear that @stop is leaving Google, but glad to know that @ireneau is still pushing forward -- http://is.gd/nVUI
I was taught to embrace adversity by leaning *in* (vs out and away) to changing circumstances. My back aches with all of you leaning in now.
@bigwags Great point. It is like we are all on the same sailboat and have to lean-in a unified direction else the boat tips over.
is thinking how *anything* you do will be done more wrong until you learn how to do it more right.
is elaborating on a Twitter post from long ago about punctuations marks http://is.gd/oKIO
is having an epiphany that if RISD stands for "Reason I'm Sleep Deprived," then he's happily living the RISD way.
is thinking how he's always treated students as adults because that's how they become professionals and 1st class citizens.
overheard a nice phrase, "It's nice to be important, but it's important to be nice."
notes that having an ego is usually healthy and fine. It's how you build the ego that determines whether it is truly deserved.
@bwycz I like your point on the question of one's sense of peace. Peace to all of you today.
I've been forever told, "When you are new to something you think you can take it all on. Give it up." Artists don't give up. Ever.
to dismissively say, "No they can't." neglects the fact that *they* are a part of *we* in "Yes we can."
@johnmaeda I disagree - a little bit. I'm an artist - I give up at least twice a day. The difference is I start again. (via @heidirettig)
is stuck on the ground at JFK and having an existential moment as to how many people on this flight are blogging or tweeting right now.
all the input on FB and Twitter made me wonder who just got in late to LAX? Perhaps just me. No electronic ghosts.
is curious how individualism can become a team sport.
Thanks -- @johnmaeda you have to learn (and teach) that one can win without making others lose (via @jimhill)
is in SF to connect with close to 200 RISD alums, parents, and supporters. In LA heard gleeful stories about the empowering force of RISD.
likes the sign for a business spotted in LA that realizes the fusion of two worlds -- SIGN-TIST -- design and science. Well ... sort of.
is thinking how #RISD is the authentic symbol of American right-brainedness that our world needs right now.
Business adapts to societal norms, whereas artists often do the opposite to avoid being populist. There is good reason to either approach.
from my scribbled notes from hearing someone in the world: "Revel in the unresolved." + "What you define as waste, I define as joy." Pretty.
likes what #RISD Provost Jessie Sheffin says about decision-making, "It's not about top-down or bottom-up -- it's about working together."
wisdom from Tony in #RISD Public Safety for emergency response situations, "Your pulse rate should always be lower than your patient's."
insecurity & vulnerability are weaknesses that when managed with courage (vs fear) embody humility -- a leader's greatest strength.
speaking to fellow on the phone from S. Africa pitching that we work together ... using a lovely phrase that we need to "hunt in pairs."
Thanks @zoheba -- I missed out on that part in biology class but can imagine it.
the common occurrence of "human error," although often handled by poor leaders in a dehumanizing way, is essential to the human experience.
Winning an argument is less important than coming to a solution.
@tmtek I often wonder about the subjectivity of "right" -- when viewed from opposing sides. Being objectively opposed doesn't happen.
saying you are sorry is only meaningful if your ego has left the room.
only two more days until the first #RISD What We Do event ... http://tinyurl.com/cml2hf
recalls a former MIT colleague on the science of learning -- it happens particularly quickest when u r disoriented. Get lost, then found.
A fact is an idea that has evolved into an ideal. Evolution doesn't get it right always.
@g33kski11z Mathematical facts are certainly different, and I like @narinda's point on justice. Thanks.
On brevity, #RISD Provost Shefrin tells me that a 1-sentence thought makes u wonder, "What comes after?" The after-Tweet is key.
is contemplating a commonsense derivation for the volume of a sphere. Cylinders are so much easier.
sometimes u need to let go of who u r or what u r so that u can learn why u r u, especially when it counts.
Integrity comes natural to the artist because it is the raw material that invisibly dominates her work -- *honesty* is the medium of choice.
told to me by a new friend from India, "if you come upon an elephant, walk around it."
Meetings exist to promote communication; rules exist to demote communication.
Misinformation is B-list info that underwent plastic surgery to get on the A-list.
The difference between closing or opening your eyes is the choice between the imagined vs real. Blinking is only human.
@hotlou Fair enough. Thanks. JM
No coincidence that #RISD graduates founded 2 of the 5 startups in this week's TIME article on neue entrepreneurs. http://is.gd/t8zc
The artist's inhuman passion for perfection can only be managed by attention to her own mental, physical, and relational health.
RT Provocative: "Enough of the Great Depression analogies" http://www.newsweek.com/id/194609 (via @TEDchris)
Self-confidence comes from w/in and w/out oneself. Same w/self-doubt. To live both selves is to w/stand the truth.
I was cautioned to distinguish between learning and knowledge. Maybe I learned something.
After watching Dora the Explorer I'd have to say I'd trade my iPhone for a "Map and Backpack" bundle any day.
In the diner of working-life when the toast gets burnt or you're out of OJ, a side order of apologies makes the meal.
recalls his smartest professor at MIT who was never shy to respond, "Sorry, I don't know."
Thought I was running a 5K race today, but it is a 5-miler it seems. Whoops. I like the metric system better.
@OnurOrhon my European friends certainly tell me so. Personally I an partial to millimeters. Live them more than 16ths of inches.
@heidirettig Reminds me to think about post-meeting time and what it means. Thank you.
@jorgensen_ian I made it by thinking without units and just counting 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.
Japanese people are the only folks I know that get hungry when they visit an aquarium. #Toshiba friend reminded me of that.
The upside of overworking is in those rare cases where you feel you actually got something done.
#RISD frosh said 1st term was hard and now 2nd term is easy as it's routine. She misses 1st term -- artists yearn to struggle.
@ematamoros Simplicity is about subtracting the obvious and adding the meaningful. (10th law of simplicity)
"Corporate" is thought in academia to mean "unfeeling." This stereotype is unproductive. Let's celebrate companies that *feel*.
Reflecting #RISD Grad student Lauren Mackler said over dinner last nite about narratives, "Failure makes a better story."
@Egnaro Thanks. Making art is as *real* as it gets thus failure is so natural to the artist.
Useful-> "slides and documents aren't the point: discussion and decisions are" - Kim Goodwin #ux #design (via @amyhillman)
The discipline of not-for-profit work is if u feel the organization owes you something, then u'r not focused on the mission.
Work is easier when it's just work; it's much harder when you really care.
@roonoid I like your "flipped" Tweet. Thanks, JM
@not_yet I agree that "bureaucracy" has both negative and positive connotations. Where we stand changes what we see. That's why we move.
Met CEO of RI mfg firm Tacohvac when asked "How do you lead your people?" Responds, "I don't *lead*. I *love* my people."
Stereo-types make it perilously easy to think in "mono."
From friend: When ur young, ur told u have potential; when ur old, ur praised for what you did. Always b told u have potential.
The rocking chair Is a cross between a stool and a treadmill. What other #designhybrids exist?
My favorite scene in Wall-E is when he isn't sure where to place the "spork." #designhybrids being collected: http://is.gd/uudi
Institutional memory smartly skews decisions in the present towards successful past outcomes. Forward leverages backwards.
The pride expressed in a child's loss of a baby tooth is the rare case in life when losing is winning. "Just 1? I lost 5!"
Effective listening is at least 66% of effective communicating. That's why we have 2 ears to 1 mouth.
Even when everyone's on the same team, each person deserves to be treated as a unique individual.
Artists make art. Art makes artists.
@drwave intro'd Angus as a #RISD grad to me at Pixar -- "Angus MacLane came up with that (spork) gag in WALL-E." RT@drwave
Spring is in fashion on earth.
Thirst versus hunger for knowledge is subtly different. I'm unsure which is better. How you get full is important tho.
In the best meetings there are usually more wannacomes than havetacomes.
Humor keeps me human.
The idea of "here" is becoming more of an "idea" than the specific places it one signified.
#RISD alum Gus Van Sant speaking in the RISD auditorium now. Referring to Goodwill Hunting and how story built on 1 scene.
An "open invitation" is an open invitation not to come.
@necannon The #RISD auditorium was packed. Gus made everyone smile and aspire to great (and teeny little) works.
@a_maniac No, the scene where Damon and Robin Williams (the shrink) first meet, and Damon's character speaks ill of the shrink's wife.
A #RISD student suggested to improve my time mgmt skills by counting in secs instead of mins. I get 60 times more time now!
I'm a Moo fan so was glad to connect with @richardmoross -- small is not only beautiful, but memorable.
